heading: Welcome
text: Welcome Coorong Dynamics Model (\(\mathbf{CDM}\)) information pages!

heading: Project background
text: Coorong unique coastal ecosystem important supporting local culture, economy, environment, recognised globally Ramsar-listing. However, state Coorong degraded significantly past decade, primarily due reduction freshwater flows accumulation nutrients resulting changes water quality.avoid degradation help restore ecosystem, Healthy Coorong Healthy Basin (HCHB) program established Commonwealth South Australian Governments 2019. HCHB Program supports number scientific trials, investigations -ground works help restore balance Coorong identify long term solutions.part HCHB program, Coorong Dynamics Model (CDM) developed gain insights nutrient cycling habitat changes within Coorong ecosystem assist Coorong management decision making. previous version CDM developed applied assessing environmental benefits Commonwealth Environmental Water ecological habitat, recently Coorong Infrastructure Investigations Project (CIIP) assess environmental effect water quality habitat. Within HCHB program, key areas CDM development update core data inputs HCHB science investigations nutrient cycling studies ecological habitats surveys, integrate data best modelling tools help improve functional capability CDM capturing Coorong environmental conditions.report documents development CDM, including data integration knowledge generation activities within HCHB program. Improvements model functional capability, detailed validation tests, assessment management climate scenarios reported .

heading: Report layout and guidance
text: documentation structured allow systematic description model rationale, model description testing, finally results model context assessing management options. document starts introduction site general model approach, including overview opf previous modelling work Coorong research challenges knowledge gaps motivated present work. second chapter “Coorong Dynamics Model” describes details CDM platforms, configuration approach data-model integration. third chapter “Model Development Testing” describes model integration development HCHB science projects. followed integrated assessment CDM (“Integrated assessment CDM”) available Coorong data. Finally, section “Scenario testing management” reports outcomes process scenario assessment, considers nutrient management scenarios, flow variation scenarios, climate change scenarios informed HCHB analyses Lastly, major conclusions recommendations current project provided.

text: ’re unfamiliar writing .Rmd .md files, RStudio IDE 1.4 release implements visual markdown editor minimises need learn syntax. use feature, open .Rmd .md file click visual editor button top right-hand corner editor window. now see live-rendered version document addition numerous buttons/menus provide GUI formatting. heading: 1.1 Background and significance of the Coorong
1.1.1 Importance of the Coorong
text: Coorong recognised unique ecosystem essential overall health Murray–Darling Basin, recognised globally Ramsar-listing. key functions Coorong include supporting wide range wild life well local culture economy. recognition importance Ramsar-listed Coorong well declining condition Coorong South Lagoon, Commonwealth South Australian Governments jointly funded HCHB program support long-term health Coorong.

heading: 1.1.2 Ecological Character of the Coorong
text:
Coorong shallow narrow saline hypersaline lagoon, runs north-west south-east, parallel South Australian coast ~110 km separated sea sand barrier (Figure 1). constricted channel connection sea towards north-western end, referred Murray Mouth. Mouth allows exchange sea water main body Coorong. River Murray water also enters Lake Alexandrina regulated flow, suitable conditions, Murray Mouth-Coorong region via five barrage structures (Tauwitchere, Mundoo, Ewe Island, Boundary Creek Goolwa).Coorong naturally splits halfway North South Lagoons narrow constriction (Hell’s Gate Parnka Channel) width approximately 100 m. average widths North South Lagoons 1.5 km 2.5 km respectively, average depths 1.2 m 1.4 m respectively (Gibbs et al. 2018). South Lagoon receives inputs fresh brackish water network drains South-East region South Australia, discharging Salt Creek. discharge can regulated via structures Morella Basin (immediately upstream Salt Creek), drainage network. Groundwater discharge zones exist along length Coorong, perched freshwater lenses regional unconfined aquifer, hydraulic gradients relatively low (Barnett 2018).
Coorong system important habitat waterbirds, supporting 1% global populations nine waterbird taxa (Paton et al., 2009). region recognised Wetland International Importance Ramsar Convention. Furthermore, Lower Lakes Coorong important refuge waterbirds, hosting 90% waterbirds counted icon sites Murray-Darling Basin drought (Kingsford Porter, 2008). However, like Australian estuaries coastal wetlands (Kingsford, 2000), Coorong increasingly threatened ecological health eroded river regulation extraction water. Waterbird populations declined least 30% since 1985 (Paton et al., 2009) low flows led decreased fish abundance (Brookes et al., 2015). Freshwater flows Murray Mouth Coorong help maintain open Murray Mouth, maintain connectivity diadromous fish modify water level salinity Coorong, shapes habitat biota. Freshwater flows important maintaining estuarine habitat ecosystem health preventing extreme hyper-salinity (Brookes et al. 2009), influenced flows barrages. Salinity identified key driver fish distribution assemblage structure influencing extent estuarine fish habitat Coorong (Ye et al. 2011; 2016a; Bice et al. 2018; Brookes et al., 2021). Early summer flows likely particularly beneficial delay drop water level South Lagoon can prevent extreme salinities emerging, thereby improving habitat conditions key fish species.
Figure 1.1: Lower Lakes Coorong. freshwater lakes isolated marine water five barrages. Exchange ocean occurs Murray Mouth, located near Goolwa. Coorong comprised North South lagoons. Source: …

heading: 1.1.3 Management challenges
text: major management challenge Coorong long-term decline ecological condition due reductions inflows restricted exchange ocean. Whilst recovery elements Coorong ecosystem associated increased inflows since Millennium Drought, South Lagoon recovered levels expected. switch ecosystem dominated aquatic plants algae associated eutrophication (nutrient enrichment), subsequent impacts invertebrates, fish waterbirds. changes ecosystem lack recovery likely caused number complex, interacting factors, well understood. limiting capacity forecast ecological response future management scenarios therefore capacity water managers identify management interventions required improve health Coorong.

heading: 1.2 Need for an integrated model to support Coorong management
text: use water quality models management coastal water well recognised. past years, development mathematical modelling rapid (Stolarska & Skrzypski, 2012) many models utilized date coastal management. development application water quality models can support decision making identifying nutrient reduction targets (Kim et al., 2014; Waltham et al., 2014), controls harmful algal blooms (Chung et al., 2014; Robson Hamilton, 2004), public health risks (Hipsey et al., 2008), quality aquatic habitat (Brown et al., 2013).Coorong, ongoing challenges managing degrading water quality habitats drying climate, alongside management objectives, led following priority areas model tools needed support management:Whole estuary water balance nutrient budgetsNutrient paths dynamicsRe-construction historical changes habitat changesAssessment scenarios related management options climate change

heading: 2.1 Overview
text:
Coorong Dynamics Model (CDM) single model, system models can configured applied various ways different purposes.core, consists hydrodynamic model TUFLOW-FV water quality model AED, can optionally linked SWAN wave model. Different model domain resolution can selected /time-periods interest simulated. Different levels model complexity (.e., biogeochemical ecological components) can engaged within environment common input files output analysis workflows. flexibility allows common approach used different use-cases; example, long-term low-resolution simulation vs high-resolution habitat restoration can share common model settings, parameters parameterisations.general, models configured resolve hydrodynamics flushing, water temperature salinity, numerous water quality attributes including oxygen, nutrients (organic inorganic), phytoplankton, macroalgae, suspended sediment. outputs modules used predict ecological attributes interest, including seagrass, fish benthic macro-invertebrates.CDM also individual models. model links large volume data historical surveys, real-time data streams recent experimental work. Complex integration workflows implemented process data model inputs (e.g., boundary conditions) model assessment (e.g., calibration validation).
CDM therefore model-data ‘ecosystem.’ Model data provenance therefore high priority data model products developed strict version control within shared analytics platform ensure traceability transparency model use assumptions.following sections describe model platforms, detail CDM configuration, outline data-model integration management framework.

heading: 2.2.1 Hydrodynamics: TUFLOW-FV
text: TUFLOW-FV finite volume hydrodynamic model, developed BMT Global Pty Ltd (BMTWBM, 2019). flexible-mesh accounts variations water level, salinity, temperature, density response tides, inflows surface thermodynamics. current version various use-ability features including integration QGIS optimisiation operation desktop GPU resources.TUFLOW-FV used extensively region hydrological assessments. Within CDM two(three) different model domains applied different levels spatial resolution, including 2D 3D implementations.

text: Simulating WAves Nearshore (SWAN) model numerical wave model used obtain realistic estimates surface wave parameters coastal areas, lakes, estuaries given wind, bottom, current conditions. model based wave action balance equation (energy balance absence currents) sources sinks. SWAN third-generation wave model first-, second-, third-generation options.

heading: 2.2.3 Water quality and habitat: AED
text: Aquatic EcoDynamics (AED ) water quality model community-driven library modules algorithms simulation “aquatic ecodynamics” - water quality, aquatic biogeochemistry, biotic habitat aquatic ecosystem dynamics, developed AED research group UWA (Hipsey et al., 2019). module aims based state---art science sourced wide variety scientific literature, making library one advanced available aquatic ecosystem modellers.

heading: 2.3.1 Simulation domains
text:
CDM modelling domain spans Murray Mouth region south end Coorong, length ~116 km total area ~237 km2.Two types model mesh developed support different research purposes. first fine-resolution mesh (26250 cells mean cell size ~1×104 m2, Figure 2.1, left); mesh used resolving spatial heterogeneity water quality response, especially habitat predictions; second relatively coarse resolution mesh (2202 cells mean cell size ~1.3×105 m2, Figure 2.1, right) faster simulations investigating water balance modelling experiments. fine- coarse-mesh models share boundary conditions bench-marked , can used different stages model development.

heading: 2.3.2 Boundary conditions
text:
Regardless model domain / mesh option chosen, CDM system manages several standard boundary conditions allow model forced tidal, meteorological inflow information, brought together various data sources.Tidal conditions: Set ocean side Murray Mouth, open water level boundary specified based Barker Knoll / Victor Harbour tidal data, available 10 minute resolution.Salk Creek inflow: Inflow South Lagoon local catchment via Salt Creek set based available flow data water.data.sa.gov.au (curated South Australian Department Environment Water). nutrient boundary condition inputs extrapolated based field measurements Salt Ck.Barrage flows: Modelled inflow boundary conditions based historical daily-interval measurements flow rate, temperature, salinity. nutrient boundary condition inputs extrapolated based field measurements Lake Alexandrina, close barrages.Meteorology: Meteorological conditions based data Narrung weather station nearby Coorong (Figure **). spatially -resolved Bureau Meteorology Atmospheric High-Resolution Regional Reanalysis Australia (BARRA) climate model also available can used, note product discontinued beyond 2019.
Figure 2.3: Summary locations relevant boundary condition data collected /applied.

heading: 4.1.1 Overview
text:
Whilst Coorong naturally saline hyper-saline lagoon, freshwater flows important maintaining estuarine habitat ecosystem health preventing extreme hyper-salinity (Brookes et al. 2009). Ruppia tuberosa important macrophyte Coorong provides habitat fish food herbivorous birds (Phillips Muller 2006), can tolerate salinity higher natural seawater. therefore known concentrate mid southern regions (Figure 4.1).  germination growth R. tuberosa known governed large part changes salinity water level regimes, influenced flows barrages (Kim et al. 2013). factors influence R. tuberosa growth include nutrient availability, water temperature, sediment quality interactions algae, including shading light interference flowers fruits surface. Early summer flows thought particularly beneficial delay drop water level South Lagoon can prevent extreme salinities emerging, thereby encouraging complete reproductive cycle (Collier et al. 2017).addition, salinity also identified key driver influences fish assemblage structure extent estuarine fish habitat Coorong (Ye et al. 2011). section describes simulations Ruppia estuarine fish habitat configured assessed.

heading: 4.2.2 Model application
text:

heading: 4.3.2 Model description: Fish HSI
text:
fish model calculates probabilities habitat suitability juveniles seven key species, mulloway (Argyrosomus japonicus), black bream (Acanthopagrus butcheri), greenback flounder (Rhombosolea tapirina), yelloweye mullet (Aldrichetta forsteri), congolli (Pseudaphritis urvillii), Tamar goby (Afurcagobius tamarensis) smallmouth hardyhead (Atherinosoma microstoma), based laboratory experiment-derived salinity thresholds (Table 2. Ye et al. 2016a).model adopts seasonal effect account temperature sensitivity salinity thresholds (higher salinity tolerance lower temperatures), according functions parameters described Table 1 Table 2.
